title: 103_hr107
content:
The Act is titled the "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" and it applies to certain regulations. The "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress, including the Social Security Act and National Labor Relations Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws to Congress, including the Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act, Age Discrimination in Employment Act, Occupational Safety and Health Act, Title IX, Rehabilitation Act, Privacy Act, Age Discrimination Act, Ethics in Government Act, and Americans with Disabilities Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws to Congress, including the Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act, Age Discrimination in Employment Act, Occupational Safety and Health Act, Title IX, Rehabilitation Act, Privacy Act, Ethics in Government Act of 1978, and Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The Act also subjects Congress to the Freedom of Information Act and the Independent Counsel Provisions. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to various individuals including Senators, Representatives, employees of Congress, elected officers, Capitol Police members, and employees of Congressional instrumentalities. Employees of Congressional instrumentalities, including the Congressional Research Service, General Accounting Office, and Library of Congress, are subject to the laws outlined in the Congressional Accountability Act of 1993. District or State offices of Members are treated as affiliated branches of private employers under the Act. Members may consider political affiliation in certain circumstances. Section 2 outlines that a Member of Congress can consider political affiliation and place of residence when hiring staff. A conforming amendment repeals a section of the Americans with Disabilities Act. The small business exemption applies to Members based on the number of employees they have. In this subsection, the number of employees attributed to a Member is calculated by adding the employees working in the District of Columbia and employed by the House where the Member sits, then dividing by the number of Members in that House. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS.

Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the House of Representatives and the Senate must create rules to implement the Act, in line with Federal law. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations.

SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL.

Individuals affected by actions under this Act can appeal in Federal court with the same rights as private individuals under relevant laws.
